Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: You just realized a comment you made has deeply hurt your I04iend's feelings, and you need to call them right now to apologize and clear the air.
Story: I sat in my room, the family’s voices drifting up from downstairs as they prepared for the ceremony. My mother had just asked me to lead the ritual this year, saying it was time I took on more responsibility and showed respect for our traditions. I knew how much this meant to her, to everyone—being the eldest, I was expected to set an example, to honor our family’s values. But as I rehearsed the words I’d have to say, my phone buzzed with a message from my best friend. She’d seen my careless comment in the group chat, and her reply was short, cold. My stomach twisted with guilt. I knew I’d hurt her, and I needed to call her right away, to explain, to apologize before things got worse. But downstairs, my family was waiting, expecting me to step up, to be present, to lead. I stared at my phone, torn between the weight of my family’s expectations and the urgent need to fix things with my friend, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
